stem: The nurse is assisting with gastric lavage for a client with an acute medication overdose. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Instill 200â€“300 mL of room-temperature saline into the stomach.
Aspirate the stomach contents or allow them to drain by gravity.
Position the client in the left lateral decubitus position (head down).
Continue the intervals until the returned fluid is clear.
Insert a large-bore orogastric tube and verify placement.

rationale.correct: Gastric lavage (stomach pumping) should be used judiciously. (1) Position prevents aspiration and slows gastric emptying into the duodenum. (2) Large-bore (36-40 Fr) is needed to remove pill fragments. (3/4) Cycling small amounts of fluid prevents forcing poison into the small intestine. (5) Clear return indicates completion.
rationale.incorrect: Lavage is contraindicated if the ingestion occurred more than 1 hour ago or for caustic substances (which damage the esophagus twice).
clinicalPearls: Have suction equipment and a tracheal intubation kit at the bedside. The greatest risk during lavage is pulmonary aspiration.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Left is Best' because the stomach's exit (pylorus) points to the right. Gravity keeps the poison in the stomach where you can reach it.

reviewUnits.heading: Poisoning and Overdose: Gastric Decontamination
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for hypothermia if cold saline is used and assess for esophageal perforation. Activated charcoal may be administered after lavage.
